item.title: Ticket #1116 (fread() warning when saving a template with no data) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description:
Patch changed

Patch changes: if (!$error) {

to: if (!$error && filesize($real_file) > 0) {

We don't want to try reading the file if it has zero length. Thanks, anonymous!

item.title: Ticket #1115 (Move comment_form do_action() above submit button) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1115 (Move comment_form do_action() above submit button) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1115 (Move comment_form do_action() above submit button) created
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description:
The comment_form hook is awesome... but its default position (below the submit button) is limiting. The hook is useful for adding checkboxes like "subscribe to comments" and the like, but those checkboxes don't make as much sense below the submit button as they would make above.

I think a much better location for the comment_form do_action() would be right between the comment box and the submit button.

item.title: Ticket #1103 (Move RSS feed update for dashboard to pseudo cron) updated
item.dc:creator: idanso
item.description:
rss-functions.php, line 567-569:

Correct:-)

In addition, it appears that the caching system itself was not crippled, but It used the DB(specificly, the options table, except that it doesn't seem it was designed for that purpose) to store the cache data.

My patch actually makes it work on a file-system cache once again, which has it trade-offs:-)

item.title: Ticket #1110 (Admin can add a user with [space] as nick name) updated
item.dc:creator: gzfelix
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1110 (Admin can add a user with [space] as nick name) created
item.dc:creator: gzfelix
item.description:
In the admin panel, Users/Authors & Users, the admin can add a user with [space] as nick name.

Reproduce:

  1. Add a user with [space] as its nick name, fill the email and password fields.
  2. Promote this user.

As a side effect, this user is always logged in, so you cannot comment a post. In the Leave a reply page, it always shows that Logged in as (empty).

item.title: Ticket #1108 (Conflicting PHP file with same name as Page slug.) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: The default rewrite rules purposefully avoid eclipsing files that exist in the filesystem by checking to see if %{REQUEST_FILENAME} exists. Perhaps mod_rewrite resolves this to any file with a matching basename, regardless of extension.

item.title: Ticket #1108 (Conflicting PHP file with same name as Page slug.) updated
item.dc:creator: Kafkaesqui
item.description: After a bit more testing I see this is not just an issue with PHP files. It seems any file type will do it (tried about.txt, about.doc and about.jpg!), as long as it's using the same filename.

item.title: Ticket #1109 (DB choking on duplicate category names) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1109 (DB choking on duplicate category names) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I was making sub-cats for a section of my blog when I tried to make a "Funny" category. I already had one, and instead of a nice "Sorry, name already taken" error, I got "BLARGHHGRHHRHGHRHHGH DATABASE ERROR YOU FOOL!!!!!"

bascially, it's just not premptivly checking for duplicates and returning a nasty error.

  • Jeff Minard

item.title: Ticket #1108 (Conflicting PHP file with same name as Page slug.) updated
item.dc:creator: Kafkaesqui
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1108 (Conflicting PHP file with same name as Page slug.) created
item.dc:creator: Kafkaesqui
item.description: If a php file residing in the root directory of the weblog (with wp-blog-header.php, etc.) has a filename matching that of an existing Page slug, WordPress uses that PHP file instead of the default, theme or custom template. For example, the file "about.php" loads when accessing the "about" Page.

item.title: Ticket #825 (Query based templates not fully armed/operational) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
I'm convinced and consider this closed: ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic.php?id=24266

The only other consideration would be the author-#.php templates, but these can be handled with a plugin (thus preventing more file_exist()'s - the same argument you mentioned regarding the date based templates).

item.title: Ticket #825 (Query based templates not fully armed/operational) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
paged.php probably should be eliminated. It's a botched experiment.

I see little utility in year.php and friends. Are people actually building themes like this? I'd like to see a practical use of these templates that wouldn't be done better with is_year() inside of date.php or archive.php. Otherwise, it's just another set of file_exists() checks for templates that will be little used.

item.description: Owner, Status changed

item.title: Ticket #1096 (Resetting admin password results in extra notification e-mail) updated

item.description: Trivial fix attached(untested)

item.title: Ticket #1103 (Move RSS feed update for dashboard to pseudo cron) updated
item.dc:creator: idanso
item.description:
And actually, the caching funcionality is on, by default, but there is no "cache" folder in the wp-includes directory for it to take advantage of.

It is not - MAGPIE_CACHE_ON constant is not defined, thus the cache is disabled.

Even if it will be set to on, I still had to port some up-to-date code from recent Magpie to actually make it working.

item.title: Ticket #825 (Query based templates not fully armed/operational) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Further reports of year.php, month.php & day.php failing: <a href="​http://wordpress.org/support/topic.php?id=24266">​http://wordpress.org/support/topic.php?id=24266</a>.

These query templates are presumably meant to work as documented in Codex and elsewhere, so I'd be inclined to consider this a bug rather than a feature request.

item.title: Ticket #1103 (Move RSS feed update for dashboard to pseudo cron) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I use Feed On Feeds as my news reader (it utilizes Magpie), and even with caching on, it can still take a while to parse a few feeds. I just don't think people should be left waiting after hitting the "login" button.

Perhaps the update could be run once every hour via a shutdown hook that tracks the "last updated" time.

And actually, the caching funcionality is on, by default, but there is no "cache" folder in the wp-includes directory for it to take advantage of.

Not to mention that fact that Magpie is at v0.71, and the included one is 0.51 - I wonder what the reason for that is - can't be an oversight, right?

item.title: Ticket #1105 (Link category selection from keyboard) updated
item.dc:creator: kim
item.description:
To provide a more uniform UI to match with the suggested change, I modified the list of link categories (wp-admin/link-categories.php) to also sort by category name rather than ID by default. However, at times it can be useful to be able to locate a category easily by its ID number, so I also added sort order selection through links in the table heading cells (by ID and by name).

Second attached patch implements this.

item.title: Ticket #1061 (Patch demonstrating more advanced styling of "active" resources) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Owner, Status changed

item.title: Ticket #1060 (Patch to add "active" class values to active plugins and themes) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Owner, Status changed

item.title: Ticket #1105 (Link category selection from keyboard) updated
item.dc:creator: kim
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1105 (Link category selection from keyboard) created
item.dc:creator: kim
item.description:
When adding a link (wp-admin/link-add.php) the list of categories is sorted by ID and has the ID prepended to the category name. To select a category using the keyboard, one would need to remember the numeric ID of the category.

I think usability would increase if the list was sorted by category name, so that the category can be selected by typing the first letter of the category (repeating the keypress will cycle down entries beginning with the same letter).

Attached patch implements this change.

item.description: On Unix PHP's builtin mail function only works when sendmail is available (which is not the case on all systems). Please provide a custom SMTP mail function which can be used instead of the builtin function.

item.title: Ticket #1004 (A less privileged user's post 'disappears' after they make an edit) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description:
I think arguments can be made for both policies (disallowing further edits, and allowing further edits.)

However, if edits are allowed, it seems wrong to make the post disappear (EDIT: to clarify, make the post disappear from the public side of the blog). What would be ideal is that the edits are submitted as a draft revision, while the original post remains published. Pretty much impossible given the current structure. I've been trying to think of a way that this could be accomplished. All I can think of is that on edit, an additional post is created with a status of "revision draft", that has some sort of "is_revision_of" value that points to the original post. If the admin approves the changes, they are put into the post that has already been published, and the temporary "revision draft" is destroyed.

The "new users can submit drafts" process is quite young, and it would be good to give it some more consideration, trying to think of how it might be used.

I used the process in 1.3 CVS to run a blog with over 150 users that could submit drafts. I hacked the interface quite a bit in order to make things better.

Some thoughts: Users who can submit drafts should not be able to edit each others posts... only their own. They also should not be shown the Dashboard screen... too confusing. Also, it isn't obvious to new users what button they should press to submit a post for approval (see here: ​http://mosquito.wordpress.org/view.php?id=1097 ). There needs to be a better way of notifying the admin that posts are waiting for approval (see here: ​http://mosquito.wordpress.org/view.php?id=1098 )

Also, it's not really obvious who has submitted a post for approval to the admin. All he gets is a list of draft titles. Perhaps we need a subpage of "Manage" that has a "drafts queue" page. If this whole "submit drafts for approval" concept were fleshed out, it could really open up a lot of possibilities for group blogs.

edited on: 03-14-05 02:40

item.title: Ticket #1103 (Move RSS feed update for dashboard to pseudo cron) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1103 (Move RSS feed update for dashboard to pseudo cron) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
It's quite annoying to goto my admin, login, and then wait anywhere from 1 second to 2 minutes while Magpie takes its sweet time updating the RSS feed for the dashboard.

It would be prudent to optimize this behaviour or move it to a shutdown hook or *something*.

  • Jeff Minard
